section.title: Matching Elements
section.p: The longest-common-subsequenced is calculated to find the best allignment â€“ not prioritized by the number of elements but by the length of the content. Elements with same base-class are first matched by their ids:

sl.sli: dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy
eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et dolore magna aliquyam erat,

section.p: Elements are also matched by equalty. So identical elements are alligned even when there is no id attribute:

sl.sli: dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy
eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et dolore magna aliquyam erat,

section.p: But there is no matching by similarity. So when elements are reorganized and modified the allignment no more works:

sl.sli: dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy
eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et dolore magna aliquyam erat,

li.p: Changed tagging: italic1 nested italic2 single-word
Link with changed explicit content: Renamed link text (new)
Single letter changed per word: Text Text

ul.li: Changed tagging with ph-element won't be highlighted.

li.p: Longer text with multiple changes: This is some text where some words will be the same but the total meaning has changed. Thus, it makes no sense to compare the text word by word.

section.title: Fixed Link Target
section.p: Some more Text to increase the size of this node so it is less likely to be moved.

section.title: Tables
section.p: Table columns are matched by alligning the elements of the first row. Added columns for deleted rows and deleted columns for added rows are completed as blank cells. (The colname is normalized during the DITA-OT preprocessing so this information can not be used for matching the columns.)
